div.p: THE She-Gallants: A COMEDY. As it is Acted at the THEATRE IN Little-LINCOLN-INN-FIELDS, BY His MAJESTY's Servants.
LONDON: Printed for Henry Playford in the Temple-Change. And Benj. Tooke at the Middle-Temple-Gate in Fleet street. 1696.

div.head: THE PREFACE TO THE READER.
div.p:
THIS Play was Written by the Author in France above twelve Years past, without any design of becoming Publick, but only as an Exercise to learn to Write, at an Age when many are but beginning to Spell. It was afterwards accidentally communicated to some Persons, and begg'd by a Friend, who propos'd to make some Advantage by it, which was consented to upon Promise that the Author should never be nam'd. Thus it remain'd for some Years in other Hands, till at last the Author was importun'd to own it, or his Friend had been
disappointed. Some few Alterations were made to suit it only to the present time of Acting; in every thing else the Play is the same as at first, even to the Songs, and the Epilogue as it is printed. If his Friend has had a Third Day to his Satisfaction, it is all the end that the Author propos'd to himself: And if before the ordinary Age of Manhood, he shall be allow'd not to have been wholly Impotent, it is all the Commendation he expects. Of which the Reader is left to judge as he thinks fit.

div.head: Prologue to the SHE-GALLANTS, Spoke by Mr. BETTERTON.

lg.l: AS quiet Monarchs that on peaceful Thrones
In Sports and Revels long had Reign'd like Drones:
Rousing at length, reflect with Guilt and Shame,
That not One Stroke had yet been giv'n for Fame;
Wars they proclaim, and to redeem the past,
To bold Attempts and rugged Labours haste.
Our Poet so: with like Concern reviews
The Youthful Follies of his Love-sick Muse.
To Amorous Toils, and to the Silent Grove;
To Beauty's Snares, and to deceitful Love,
He bids Farewel: His Shield and Launce prepares,
And mounts the Stage, to bid Immortal Wars.
Vice, like some Monster, suff'ring none t'escape,
Has seiz'd the Town, and varies still her Shape.
Here, like a General, she struts in State,
While Crowds in Red and Blue her Orders wait.
There, like some pensive Statesman, walks Demure,
And smiles and huggs, to make Destruction sure.
Now under high Commodes with Looks Erect,
Bare-fac'd devours in gawdy Colours deck.
Then in a Vizard, to avoid Grimace,
Allows all Freedom but to see the Face.
In Pulpits and at Bar, she wears a Gown;
In Camps a Sword, in Palaces a Crown.
Resolv'd to Combat with this Motly Beast,
Our Poet comes to strike One Stroke at least.
His Glass he means, not for this Iilt or Beau,
Some Features of you all he hopes to shew
On chosen Heads; nor lets the Thunder fall,
But scatters his Artillery at All.
Yet to the Fair he sain wou'd Quarter show,
His tender Heart recoils at every Blow.
If unawares he give too smart a Stroke,
He means but to Correct, and not Provoke.

row.cell: Formerly contracted to Angelica, to be marry'd to Lucinda.
In Love with Bellamour, Daughter to Sir Toby.
A Frenthman, that dresses Heads for Ladies.
Page and Servants to Lady Dorimen.

div.head: ACT the First. SCENE I.
div.stage: Company walking to and fro as in the Mall.
Enter Angelica and Constantia in Man's Apparel.

sp.speaker: Ang. repeating,
sp.l: DIsguise your Inclinations as you can,
Yet every Woman's business is a Man.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Notwithstanding the Poet's Opinion, I declare for my part, I wou'd have seen all Mankind at the Devil, before I'de have taken so much pains for any one of 'em.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Ah Constantia! when once a Woman has got a Man in her head—.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: She never leaves till she has him— well, I say no more; but faith 'tis hard that Men should desert at this rate, and put us to such pains to bring 'em back to their Colours.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: An old Roman, as I have read, began an Oration to this purpose: If we could break off all Communication with Women, we shou'd be freed from many Troubles. Now, I say, if we Women wou'd renounce Mankind, we shou'd avoid many Evils, and be reveng'd for the past; for what cou'd they do without us?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Not so fast neither— Rather what cou'd we do without them?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: It might be somewhat uneasy, I confess, but they wou'd have the worst on't.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Not so much as you may imagine, for they have a thousand other Diversions: Nor, wou'd Love it self be altogether excluded;. for in this wicked Age, a young, spruce, handsom Fellow, is become a Rival for a fine Woman. And I'le pawn my Breeches, and all that belongs to 'em, if in this Dress we are not as much courted by the Men themselves, as when we appear'd to be Women.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Fy, Constantia, thy Breeches have made thee strangely extravagant.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Why don't you see as we walk along, how they stop and look back— Demme ' Jack, says one, a pretty young Fellow— By Iove as good as a Wench— And then a Lady with a languishing Cast, ogles over her shoulder, and whispers her Companion— I vow, my Dear, a most agreeable Creature. Upon my Reputation, such a Man is not at all my Aversion.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Of all the Conquests I have made in this habit, that which pleases me best, is my Adventure with my Lady Dorimen. It is, you know, to her Neece Lucinda, that my faithless Bellamour is to be marry'd; wherefore if I can but get into her Ladyship's Family, and have some power over her Inclinations, I hope to find an Expedient to break off a Match, which, if concluded, undoes me.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Exceeding Wise and Politick.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: My trusty Friend and Counsellor in this Intrigue, (with Reverence be it spoken) is my own lewd old Father Sir Toby Cusiste, with whom thus disguis'd, I have contracted a particular Intimacy: Whoring and Pimping have been always his Occupation— The kind Offices he does of that sort, make him every where a welcom Person. He knows me not, nor indeed is it possible he shou'd, having left me at ten years old in the Country, at random, to the care of an old Nurse, and never seen, nor scarce enquir'd after me since.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: A hopeful Father truly.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p:
How unkind soever he has been, if by his assistance I can be so introduc'd to my Lady Dorimen, as to undermine Bellamour, and reclaim his Infidelity, he will then be a Father
to me indeed; and I expect him here every minute, to give me some account of the progress he has made in it.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: This Father of your's is a most necessary Man, and has likewise been particularly useful to me upon a like occasion; for, to confess the Truth to you freely, there is some other meaning in my wearing Breeches, besides keeping you company.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Indeed I always suspected some secret Self-Interest in your Disguise, you put it on so willingly: But may not a Friend be inquisitive, and ask your Secret?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Yes, and be told it. Know then, my dear Angelica, that thô in publick I have been an Enemy declar'd to Love, yet we have held a private Correspondence together. And what may seem yet more Bizarre, the Man in the World whom I have always us'd worst, is he whom I have lov'd best. I know what Dissemblers are Men, and am resolv'd to enquire thorowly into my Lover, before I discover my Inclinations. If I find Frederick loves me sincerely, and is a Man of Honour, I will then explain my self in his favour: But if I prove him unworthy, my Aversion, that is now but Pretence, shall be real, and he shall never so much as suspect that I have had the least good thought of him.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: This Caution is much to be prais'd, and the more, because it is so very unusual to love, and be discreet at the same time.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: In pursuance therefore of this Design, I have already made a friendship with him, passing for my own Brother Courtall, whom every one knows to resemble me so entirely, that we have often, by changing of habits, been mistaken the one for the other. Thus have I many opportunities to pry into his most secret affections, to examin his humour, and sound him to the bottom: But the Jest on't is, that he has propos'd a cross Match to me, proffering me the choice of his four Sisters, provided I will undertake to persuade Constantia to relent; to which I have agreed, and have accordingly made formal Address to all four.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How! to all four!

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p:
Yes, and am hugely diverted; for, you must know, their Brother has strictly instructed 'em to be wanting in no kind of encouragement: I never rise in a morning, but I find my Toilette cover'd with Presents, Rings, Bracelets, Perfumes, and a world of fine things; for which I make equal acknowledgments
to all, and protest it most impossible to know which to chuse.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And are you not very malicious, to triumph in this manner over the weakness of your own Sex? Besides, what can this exposing the Sisters, profit any thing with the Brother?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: O let me alone to manage it; if I fail in my Ends, I'll be bound to renounce my Petticoats for ever, and never to find any thing more substantial in Breeches than what you can give me: for your Plot I don't see how it can fail, for faith I cou'd be in love with you my self, but that I know your Credentials are counterfeit, and 'tis a false Pass which you shew.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Prithee tell me truly, what manner of a Man do I make?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: A very Spark, upon Honour; and, to all outward appearances, as much a Man as the best. Any thing that's well Periwig'd, and Powder'd, and Steenkirk'd, and Embroider'd, is a Man. Singing and Dancing, and Dress, is Breeding. Noise, Familiarity and Impertinence, is Wit. Whistling to one's self— as thus— or taking Snuff gravely— as thus— passes for Thought, and serious Consideration: And all this put together, is a Man.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: At least as much as is necessary for us two at this time— But however one is a little Awkard at first— How do I walk?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Ha, an Air fieré & determineé—

div.stage: [They strut about the Stage.]

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And then my Legs, Constantia.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: 'Tis true, the Ladies love good Supporters— They'll do, they'll do, 'Sbud fear nothing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Why how now Bully, what, thou swear'st too?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Damm your Whinings and Formalities: Confound me, Madam, I adore you; Thunder rivet me, I must enjoy you— How much better this sounds than—" Durst I presume, Madam; or might I be permitted— 'Zoons, how many a modest Fool has lost his Longing, for want of Damming, Sinking, and Confounding handsomly, and like a Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Peace, Madcap— here comes my old bawdy Father, according to appointment.

div.stage: Enter Sir Toby, who runs and embraces them.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: My Ganimed— My Hylas—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: My Iupiter.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: My Hercules.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: My dear little Sparks of Love, let me kiss ye. You'r lucky Rogues both— Wrapt in your Mothers Smocks Begad— There's not a Lady in Town but lies at your mercy— (to Ang.) For your part, my little Cupid, my Lady Dorimen's your own, the least Thrust throws her flat e'gad, just you know how— I met her this minute, and she gave me such a Look, such sweet Ogles, as thus d'ye see, and thus; so very dying egad, it made my heart ake to see it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Alas! poor Lady— If she languishes in earnest, she knows her Remedy, Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: And that's heartily said i'faith: Well, she for a willing Mistress, and old Toby for a hearty Pimp, I'll say't we are the best in Christendom: But hark— I had like to have forgot— This 'tis to have so much Occupation at a time— (to Cons.) see here my Mark— Anthony.
sp.l: Twice twenty slender Virgin Fingers twine
This curious Web, where all their Fancies shine.
sp.p: Your four Mistresses beg you to accept of this Bracelet, 'tis the work of all four, compos'd of their own hairs, and wrought with their own hands.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: A thousand Thanks, dear Sir Toby— all your Offices are friendly.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby
sp.p: Hush! hush! who comes here? what, a Swarm of Beaux and Froes?
sp.stage: [Company continuing to walk in the Mall.]
sp.p: My Lord, your Lordship's— Madam, your most obedient— That's my little Lord Wagfan— That's fine Mrs. Wrigglebum.

div.stage: Sir John Airy, Vaunter, and Ladies crossing over, Sir John and Vaunter run to Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Ha, Chevalier Ierny, dear Rogue, let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Airy.
sp.p: Dear Toby, let me kiss thee. Thou'lt excuse me, Geddemme', that I don't stay with thee, but the Ladies would never forgive me: Let me go this once, and I'll make what haste I can to come to thee again, beged. Exeunt singing.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Let thee go? Who the Devil keeps thee.—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What Fools are those, Sir Toby?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Such Fools as are to be seen, but not to be describ'd; adzooks, the Town swarms with them; one is call'd Vaunter, and the other Sir Iohn Airy, Fops, with great Estates; Cullies to the Women, and Bubbles to the Men.— But who have we here.— Ay, 'tis she her self by Jove.— My Lady Dorimen in propria Persona, with her Neice Lucinda; and just behind 'em, my little Courtall, your four Cleopatra's; stay you and meet them, while we follow my Lady Dorimen.— Make your best Leg,— bow, bow, and let her pass, we'll catch her the next turn.— Now follow,— adzooks, I love Pimping dearly.

div.stage: Lady Dorimen, Lucinda, Placket cross over the Stage; Sir Toby and Angelica follow.
Enter Diana, Melissa, Dorinda, and Miranda; Constantia joyns them with the Bracelet in her Hand.

sp.speaker: Cons. repeating,
sp.l: As Nature them, so they this Shade have wrought,
Soft as their Hand, and various as their Thought.
sp.p: And did you think my Heart, Ladies, not enough your own, before that you have sent me this pretty Chain to bind it faster.

sp.speaker: Diana.
sp.p: The Ladies who sent you that Bracelet, sure meant it for a Reproach, and not for a Favour; and it seems to say, Vnconstant Man, can no one Colour please you?

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Truly, Madam, I made a more favourable Interpretation, and concluded, that the Ladies, who have been so kind to present me their Hair, meant to deliver up their Strength with it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You Men interpret every thing with vanity to your selves.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Alas, Madam, take away Hope and Vanity, you kill us; they are the Cordials that kind Nature has provided for our Comfort upon all occasions of Disgrace and Discouragement.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: If Vanity could keep you alive, the Men of this Age are so stock'd, they would be Immortal.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really, Sister, we give our Lover too many occasions to feed his Vanity, see how plump and ruddy it keeps him.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Let us resolve then for the future, to be seen only in frowns.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Till we make him look like a Lover in earnest.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: A Lover in earnest would be a strange sight indeed.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: As strange as many other things that are often discours'd of, but never seen.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Love is the pretence of all Mankind, as common in their Mouths,—

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: As Snush in their Noses;—

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: But is never to be found in their Hearts.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Besides, Men are grown such self-enamour'd things, that they neither like nor love any thing but themselves.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: And what is the whole World sway'd by, but self-affection; the Courtier sides with the great Man in hopes of Preferment; the great Man is diligent about his Prince, because he rises by him; and there is scarce a Priest who serves God, but for the sake of a Benefice.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Pray, are not your Lovers the same? for when a Man pretends a Passion; what is it he intends but to content his own Desires? You seek not to give, but to receive Pleasure, and that you call Love.— Love of your selves, indeed.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: The Friendship, Loyalty, Religion, and Love of Men serve only to cover private Ends.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: And the Virtues of Mankind are all but Vices in disguise.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Very smart and satyrical; 'tis pity Ladies, but this humour of Bitterness were encouraged; what say you to an extempore Lampoon by word of Mouth upon the whole Mall?

sp.speaker: All Women.
sp.p: With all our hearts.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really nothing so diverting, as to rail at Folks behind their Backs.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: See yonder for the Purpose, a Legion of Lords and Ladies tossing their Heads, and jetting their Tails;— let's follow, and be exceeding severe.

sp.speaker: All Women.
sp.p: We'll not spare a Man.

sp.speaker: Cons.
sp.p: Nor I a Woman. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Lucinda and Placket.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: We'll take a turn or two by our selves: my Aunt is among the Men, and won't miss us. Did you deliver the Note I sent to Bellamour?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Yes, Madam, but I vow it went against my heart.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: The truth is, he has been so arrogant of late, especially since he thought there were no longer any Obstacles to our Marriage, that I begin to be tir'd of him; and when a Woman begins to be tir'd of a Man whilst he is a Lover, she has but little encouragement to take him for a Husband.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: But there is this to be consider'd, Madam, you have your Aunt's Instructions to love him; you have given him your self great Encouragement; the whole Town has talkt of it, and what can you expect the World will think?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Why let it think; this fear of the World destroys all the satisfactions of a Woman's Life: Hang the World, a Woman that minds what the World thinks or says, had better never have been in the World.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: But what can be the reason of this sudden alteration?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I confess the absence of Philobel had almost made me forget him, and I began insensibly to feel a kind of Inclination for Bellamour: If my old Lover had not return'd, I might have made my new one the happy Man; but since I hear Philabel came last night to Town, I find my self more inclin'd to my first Promise than my last, and in this have only acted like a Woman of the Age; if one Lover had fail'd, I entertain'd another in case of necessity.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Then you are resolv'd to break with poor Mr. Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Not absolutely break with him, but suspend my Resolution till I know how Philabel continues inclin'd; for as I told you before, I must not lose both; and tho the uneasiness and jealousy of Bellamour's Temper has lost him some part of my good Will, he is yet in the Ballance.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Well, I vow Madam, methinks nothing's so pleasing as to see one's Lover jealous; sometimes in Fury, then presently at your Feet; now raging to part, then submissive for a Reconciliation; for, what's a Woman's pow'r, unless she could master a Lover of all Humours?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Yes, I would master him: I would have my Lover my Slave; a thing cast to please and obey me; like my Glove, to draw on or off as I think sitting; but then this Lover must not be jealous; that shews too much like a Contention for the Mastery; every Look and Action is to be enquir'd into, and a strict account exacted of all that's done or said. No, give me the Lover that's free, who never pries into my Affairs, who has his Secrets, and lets me have mine; for so all private Reck'nings are handsomely discharg'd, no matter for the rest, that's the Husband for me.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: But while you suffer so much main Stock to be spent abroad, there must needs run a great deal behind-hand to you. Lord! I should be so sorry to see you pick up a Husband from a Side-box at a Play, or the Gallery in St. Iames's Church, and so after the first year be forc'd to live in the Fleet, or the King's Bench.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: And why not, rather than marry a dull, sat Fool, with a great Estate, whose Faculties are all choak'd up with Flegm; a Lump, whose only sign of Life is sweating; we may melt his Grease, but not extract one wholesome Drop out of him.— No, give me a Man without a Fortune, rather than a Fortune without a Man. I had rather beg with a brisk, lively, young Fellow, than reign with a heavy, bloated, overgrown Blockhead.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Your Aunt, Madam.

div.stage: Enter Lady Dorimen, Sir Toby, Angelica, as in discourse.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Your Wits are never seen in publick with their Wives; 'tis become a point of Scandal, and passes for Demonstration of a Fool.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: To be seen with a Wife, may be one Demonstration; to have a Wife, adzooks, is another.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir Toby, you have been marri'd your self, as great an Antagonist to Marriage as you pretend to be; and as I have heard, was so pious a Husband, that in Honour to your Wives Memory, you spent a Thousand pounds in her Funeral.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Yes, Sweat-heart, for Joy, and would have spent five times that Sum to have purchas'd so glorious a Day.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Methinks you should at least express more respect for a Condition of Life, which this young Lady has determin'd so suddenly to make Choice of for her self.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Not so fully determin'd, Sir, but I shall take some time to consider of it.

div.stage: Lady Dorimen takes Sir Toby aside.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Sir Toby, if you please, a word with you in private.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: to Lucin. This would be very ill news, Madam, for Mr. Bellamour, whose impatience must needs be great to be possess'd of so much happiness.

div.stage: Enter Bellamour, observing them.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: I am not, I assure you, in such haste for a Husband, as to venture any part of my own repose to satisfy Mr. Bellamour's impatience.
And do you think it such a venture, Madam?

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: There is no judging of Men, Mr. Bellamour, by what they appear to be, while they Court us.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p:
Give me leave, Madam, to add, nor of Women, while they are courted (softly to her) at least unconstant Woman,
if I may compare your former Encouragements, with your indifference to Day.

div.stage: Lady Dorimen talking aside with Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: But are you sure he is such a one, as a Lady may with safety repose her Honour in his hands?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Her Honour, ay, adzooks, or any thing else that she has.
Hark ye, young Gentleman, my Lady desires to know if you are a Gamester; she wants a Man sometimes to pass an Evening, or so, at Piquette.— You understand me.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You might have answer'd for me; I'll never stick out at any Games my Lady shall propose.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Look ye, Madam, he will never stick out; and adzooks, I think that's as much as any reasonable Woman can desire.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Sir Toby, shall I venture my self a turn with you and your Friend alone: Neice, you won't be angry to be left with Mr. Bellamour, your Servant; we shall meet the next turn.

div.stage: Bellamour bows.— Exeunt Lady Dor. Sir Toby, and Ang.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Yes, Women are unintelligible to the most piercing and quick-sighted: Nothing is sincere in whatever they say or do: They are all Artifice and Disguise; resolving and altering without Sence or Reason; nothing is constant either in their Minds, or in their Bodies. As these are a Prey to Age and Infirmities, so are those to every frivolous Interest and idle Temptation. Their Love is never so firm and well-establish'd, but it is sacrific'd every hour to their Folly, or their Pride.—

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Enough, enough, Mr. Bellamour,— if these are your Opinions of our Sex, how are you to be believ'd, when you say you love us? For how can any thing so deform'd, as you describe Women, be belov'd?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: There is a secret Enchantment in your Persons, that bewitches us to our own Destruction.— Inconstant Lucinda, after so many obliging Encouragements! Why was this cruel Letter sent me this morning.

p.hi: YOV have been too confident of my Consent; presume no longer on my Aunts Authority: My Heart is yet my own, and while it continues so, my Person shall never be dispos'd of.— Come not near me to day.

sp.p: Why am I thus abus'd?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Come not near me to day.— Mark that command. Why am I disobey'd?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: If any mistake has happen'd to cause this Alteration, or if in ought unknowing I've transgrest, may I not be permitted to clear my Innocence?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: To make your self more guilty, is that to clear your Innocence? I will have you take notice, that I expect to be obey'd in every trifle: Let my Commands seem never so unjust or unreasonable, I say, I will be obey'd; nor will I have my Lover dare to examine the reason of what I do, but submit patiently, and expect with Resignation: While I am your Mistress, learn to behave your self like my Vassal; when I am your Wife, you may have your Revenge.

div.stage: [Re-enter Lady Dorimen, Angelica, and Sir Toby.]

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Well, I'll say't, of a Critick, my Lady Dorimen's the Critick of Criticks.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: aside to Luc. There is a secret Mystery in your Words and Actions, that must be explain'd,— but this is no time for it,— your Company returns.— I know not how to suspect your Virtue, and therefore I entreat you, Madam, if I have in any thing ignorantly offended, condemn me not unheard.
Stealing off: Mr. Bellamour, do we drive you away?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I beg your Ladiship to excuse me, I will wait on you the next turn.

div.stage: Seems to go out, but turns short, and talks aside to the Maid.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Neice, What have you been doing to Mr. Bellamour? he seem'd to leave us in a strange Disorder.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: He looks already with the careful Face of a Marry'd Man.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: He's in one of his splenatick Fits: 'Tis an Affectation the Men have got to disguise ill Humour, and ill Manners.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: See, he's return'd, and is whispering with your Maid.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Giving her some private Directions, Madam, where you may see the Pearl Necklace, the Diamond Lockets and Pendants, and the Plate for your Toilet that are to be presented upon the Wedding-day.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: That if there is any thing amiss, such Alterations may be made before-hand as are suitable to your own Fancy.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Rather bribing my Maid, to discover to him who are my Visitants, what Correspondences I keep, and a thousand such jealous enquiries.

div.stage: Plackett talking aside to Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: He a Rival! what shou'd my Mistress do with such a Whiffler? He signifies no more to a Woman, than a Fly to a Camel.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Mrs. Plackett, I repose entirely upon your Sincerity, and shall gratefully reward all your Services.

div.stage: Exit Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Plackett come hither; what has Mr. Bellamour been whispering to you?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, but only to know whether my young Lady designs for the Play or the Park, that he may accordingly order his business to be where she is to be ogl'd.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Some such amorous Enquiry I durst have sworn Neice, is not our time come to be going?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: When your Ladyship pleases.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: The Park, Madam, is still full—

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: An invincible Necessity obliges us at this time.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: That Invincible Necessity is Infinitely Disobliging.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: We must not part, Madam, but at your Coach-side.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sir Toby, you are one of those happy Men who have leave to go any where with the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Ay Child, they'll let me go as far as their Lap-Dogs or Squirrels, the Doctor or the Midwife. Alas! I may peep where I please: An Old Man is like a Beast tam'd, my Paw frights no Body.

div.stage: [Exeunt, leading the Ladies.]
div.trailer: The End of the First Act.

div.head: ACT the Second. SCENE I.
div.stage: The Scene of the PARK continues.
Enter Frederick, Diana, Melissa, Dorinda, Miranda.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: LOVE is an universal Invader: Whatever Women pretend, they are all sensible alike; the best Livers as much as the loosest Prostitutes; only with this difference, those whom we call Virtuous and Chaste, have more Pride, or a greater force of Dissimulation.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really, Brother, you'r a strange Man: I say 'tis impossible for a Woman to be in Love, and I'll maintain it.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: In Love! Lord, with what! with a filthy Man! Phogh.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: With a stiff Beard, that fetches Blood with every Kiss.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: A great pot Belly, a broad Back, and huge Legs and Arms, enough to squeeze one to pieces.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: There is another sort of Man, my good Sisters, that, perhaps, may not be so disagreeable: I mean your smooth Beaux, who's as tender and gentle as any Lady; always trickt and perfum'd like a Lady; and were it not for his Breeches, a very Lady.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really I should as soon have a Passion for a Shadow.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Truly, Sisters, methinks you'r too nice; I have seen very proper handsom Men of all sorts and sizes.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really, Sister, such a Confession do's not become the mouth of one who values her Reputation.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Men are odious Creatures I vow, and I'll live and die in the Assertion.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Young Courtall will soon make Proselytes of you all.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: He! Harmless insignificant Thing.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: One of you, if you love me, must love him. I have already told you how passionately I adore his Sister, and that he has promis'd to put me in possession of her, when ever one of you four will consent to be his Wife. Upon this Article depends my Life and Happiness; if not perform'd, I am miserable; but if perform'd, am blest for ever.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: To save a Brother's life, really much shou'd be done; but, I vow, a Man is strangely my Aversion.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: True, Sister; but when a Brother's Life's in Jeopardy.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: To day he has promis'd to determine which of the four is most his inclination; wherefore I beseech her, whom ever it is he fixes upon, to consider she has a Brother's Life and Fortune in her hands.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: If I am the Person, really I cannot agree to it, unless you confess that you are verily persuaded that I consent out of pure Love and Kindness to you, and not any Carnal Affection to the Man— And I don't at all doubt but I am the Person.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You the Person?

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Sure he has more Wit than to chuse the Oldest.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: The Oldest? You insipid Creature—

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pray cease these untimely Dissentions.

div.stage: Enter a Boy to Frederick

sp.speaker: Boy.
sp.p: Mr. Courtall, Sir, is at your Honour's house, and has directed me to acquaint the young Ladies, that he will wait there till they have done walking.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Tell him they are coming— Exit Boy.
Your Lover is waiting for you at home; I find he cannot be very disagreeable to you, since you are so ready to quarrel for him.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: For him! Really, Brother, if you think so, I will concern my self no more in this Affair; my Sisters might fall out for the Man, but I vow my Disorder proceeded from nothing but an inordinate desire to be the Instrument of your happiness.

sp.speaker: Fred.
sp.p: Pray no more words— Go home, agree among your selves, and make me happy, by making Courtall so.
How awkardly we strive to conceal our Passions!
And how apparent is the Love of these Women, in spight of their affected Aversion! It is as hard to hide True Love, as it is to dissemble Feign'd. Exit.

div.stage: Enter Sir John Aery and Vaunter.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Lucinda to be marry'd to Bellamour! Geddemme', as I hope to be sav'd, sure she wont serve me so: But hang't, all Women are Jilts, and I don't care this pinch of Snuff who has her.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Nor I, Beged; for I have taken pains to make the Town believe I have had her, and, Beged, that's all I desire with any Woman.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: And, Demme, she has made me believe a thousand times that I shou'd have her; for by all the great Geds and the little, she never sees me, but she laughs full in my face; and if to smile is a sign of being pleas'd, Beged to laugh is at least as much again.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Well interpreted, dear Sir Iecky, Beged; for where-ever I go, I observe every body laugh, and I always us'd to take it for an Affront.

sp.speaker: Sir. I. Aery.
sp.p: That's very foolish, Geddemme: Now, I never take any thing for an Affront. If a Man calls me Son of a Whore, Beged I always take it for a mark of familiarity and kindness. If any one kicks, or gives me a Box on the Ear, I take it all in good part. A very good Jest, i'faith, and I laugh till I hold my sides.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p:
Thou'rt i'th' right, Beged; for why the Devil shou'd I suppose any Man would affront a Man of my parts? Beged, 'tis less'ning one's self, and I thank thee, dear Iecky, from my Soul, for reforming me in this Error: But prithee tell me, dear
Aery, didst thou ever speak to Lucinda, that she has given the such hopes?

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Speak to her, Geddemme', No: Was ever any thing so foolish? What signifies speaking? If speaking wou'd do, why none but Men of Sense wou'd be happy; and when the Devil didst thou ever know a Man of Sense well receiv'd by a Woman?

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: That's true, by all the great Geds and the little; for I have observ'd all my life, that my Gilt Coach and Six Horses, and Footmen in Lace-Liveries, have got me more Women, than all my fine Speeches; and, Beged, I know what to say too as well as another.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Geddemme, Paux there is more Rhetorick in a Tune on the Flute passionately play'd, or a Song languishingly humour'd, than in all Cicero. And thô I can speak Sense as well as another, yet, Demme, I'm too well bred to offend the Ladies— But prithee, dear Vaunter, tell me how thou hast made the Town believe thou hast had Lucinda; for, Beged, that's a pretty sort of Vanity that I shou'd be exceeding fond of.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Why, Beged, no otherwise than thus: At Church, I always sit in the same Pew; at the Play, in the same Box; at the Musick-meeting, I contrive to be the next Man of her, and never fail to lead her out upon all these occasions. In the Park, I turn as she turns; I go out, when she goes out; I drive by her Coach, then stop, and go softly, till she goes by again; then gallop, Beged, till I overtake her once more; and so twenty times together, ogling like a Devil, till I see where she alights, there I alight too; and, Beged, she never makes a Visit, but I am up Stairs as soon as she. The World takes notice of these Assiduities, and being always glad of any opportunity to defame, my happiness is every where publisht; my Friends give me joy of my success, which I receive with an O Gad, why shou'd you think so? What can a Woman see in me? This Town is a strange place, that a man can do nothing in secret, Geddemme, I can't imagin how this came to be found out; for, beged, I took all the care in the World to be discreet, but these foolish Women always betray themselves— And so, Geddemme, half avowing, and half denying, I palm my self upon a Woman—

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: That wou'd sooner spit in thy face, than let thee kiss her—

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Ha! Right, Geddemme, as I hope to be sav'd, by all the great Geds and the little, and a very good Jest it is; and thus I got the Name of the Ladies fine Gentleman.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: But prithee, dear Vaunter, wilt not thou look like an Ass, when the world knows another man has got thy suppos'd Mistress from thee?

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Demme not at all, for I'll swear I gave my consent, and that the Fool has nothing but my leavings; and that I was seeking some handsom occasion to get rid of her, and, beged, you know the Town in always ready to believe any ill that's said of a Woman: But however, Geddemme, if I cou'd meet with this Bellamour, I shou'd be provok'd to forbid the Banes, beged, by mincing the Dog to Atoms.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Say'st thou so, Bully-Rock, beged yonder he comes— And but that it wou'd not be like men of Honour for two to fall upon one, I'd stay and help thee; so, dear Vaunter, fare thee well.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Demme, Aery, thou wilt not leave me so— See, there comes a spruce Prigg with him, that thou shalt mince.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: I'm heartily sorry, dear Vaunter, that I can't serve thee; but, Beged, I engag'd my person but last Night to a great Lady for all this day, and my person not being my own at this time, dear Rogue, you must needs excuse me Besides, my Lady Gobble tipt me the Wink just now to follow her.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Now I think better on't, why a Devil shou'd I make a noise of this matter? that wou'd look to the world like resenting some disappointment; and, Demme, I scorn the world shou'd think I was ever disappointed— But I'll tell thee what I'll do better, I'll write her a Letter by the Penny-Post, that shall give such a Character of him as shall infallibly do his business; so, dear Aery, let's about it, and then come back, and rally the poor Dog to death. Exeunt.

div.stage: Enter Bellamour and Angelica.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Women grow troublesom when they are so fond: Your Cousin Angelica might have spar'd you this trouble; I'd as live see a Ghost, as receive a remembrance from a Cast Mistress.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: You say you lov'd her once, and it is by that Love she now conjures you not to give way to any other Passion which will make her desperate, and you perjur'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I shou'd be sorry to make a Lady desperate; but if to change a Mistriss is Perjury, who is innocent?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: What Reason can you give for your change?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Faith none at all: Our Inclinations are our Masters, and we wander but as our Stars lead us; if they are false Lights, and shew us out of the way, let them answer for't. It was my fortune to see Angelica, and to love her. It was my fortune to be absent from her, and to forget her: What is there new in all this? I confess she has Beauty and Wit, and I wish her a great deal of Happiness; but there is a Luck which over-rules all, the deserving are not always the successful.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Sure Fortune will never side with Falshood and Perjury—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: O you mistake Fortune: Fortune is, as it were, an Hospital for Villany and Folly, where all are provided for, whom Nature has maim'd and disfigur'd. Mark every rude unpolish'd Owl you meet, he's sure to be some Minion of Fortune's; and every nauseous ill-favour'd Hagg, is not her Name a Fortune? The Children of this World have all different Portions; some have Wit, others Beauty: But where there is no Merit to be found, those have Fortune, which is the Cordial Drop prescrib'd by Providence to comfort 'em, for the severity and unkindness of Nature.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And so by consequence, because my Cousin Angelica has some merit, therefore she must be unfortunate.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Besides, to confess the truth, I cannot but think two years Absence has made as great an Alteration in her, as in me: Women are seldom behind-hand with us, and two years was time enough for a Woman to have chang'd two dozen of Lovers.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And is this the best Answer she is to expect from you?

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: It is. Yet, if you please, you may give it some kinder turn: I would not deal too roughly with one whom I had once lov'd, and whose Beauty and Virtues I still adimre; therefore, pray, chuse the gentlest terms you can to comfort her, and advise her to forget one who cannot but confess he has been ungrateful.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And if 'tis possible, she shall hate as much as ever she lov'd you.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Not hate me: I would not have her hate me, only not love so much; and not injure her self by any extravagance of Passion, nor by any over-fondness be burthensome to me.

div.stage: Enter Sir J. Aery and Vaunter.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Ha, Bellamour! Give thee Joy, dear Rogue; give thee Joy. The Town says thou'rt going to be marry'd, 'tis talk'd of, Geddemme, by every body at the Chocolate-house.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: By all the great Geds, and the little, is the Man possest, to condemn himself for all the Days and Nights of his Life to one body; to be bound never to change her, tho she change never so much, tho she grows never so old, so odious, so stinking, and ill-favour'd, phogh, Geddemme', to live under an eternal Persecution?

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Let me be torn by wild Horses, wrack'd alive, bury'd quick; but save me, Heaven, save me from this Holy Inquisition, call'd Marriage, beged.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: aside. These Fools for once may be useful; I'll encourage the humour.— Do not you know, Mr. Bellamour, that let the Person be never so lovely, or so much belov'd, as soon as she becomes your Wife, the Charm ends? Like enchanted Palaces that we approach with admiration, but in the instant when we think we are entring into Paradise, we find our selves in some dark Dungeon inhabited by Toads and Adders.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Do not you know, Geddemme', that let a Person be never so much an Angel before Enjoyment, she is the Devil afterwards?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Perhaps, by the continual presence of the Person, by considering her deliberately, and examining her in all Lights, we find many things wanting to our first Expectation. Perhaps a quiet and peaceable Enjoyment of any thing makes it the less valued: Or it may be, by a frequent and customary Commerce, the Pleasures of the Sence lose their quickness and vivacity.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Women are Riddles, Geddemme, past all expounding.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: To day they are one thing.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: To morrow another.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Constant to nothing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: A Compound of Whimsies, toss'd to and fro by as many Humours, as the Ocean by Winds.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Geddemme, there is no Woman's mind, but is past a Man's understanding.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: There is no being certain of what is always uncertain, beged.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And in a Country full of Precipices, who but Mad-men will leap blindfold? In a word, I can imagine no such lively Emblem of Marriage, as the Punishment for Parricides among the Ancients; where the offender was sow'd into a Bag with a Monkey, a Dog, and a Serpent; these three Companions truly represent the Character of a Wife; who is an eternal Chatterer, and full of tricks like a Monkey; or howling and snarling like a Dog; or with a forked Tongue and invenom'd Teeth, stinging and biting like a Serpent.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
Bell.
sp.p: Gentlemen, I thank you; I was once beginning to be very angry, but I find so much reason in your Remonstrances, that I esteem my self much oblig'd to you. The Counsel of Fools is not to be despis'd when 'tis good; and so your Servant. Exit Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Geddemme', Fools! who do's the unmannerly Puppy mean?

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Beged, not me; for all the World knows I am none.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I am much mistaken, Gentlemen, if he did not mean you both. (aside) Two such Originals I never saw.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Demme, a very smart Lad.— Dear Rogue, let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Ay, dear Rogue, let me kiss thee, for thou and I must be better acquainted. Beged, thou'rt a Rump-Jewel for a Prince.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: By your leave, Gentlemen, these Lips are reserv'd for better occasions.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Ah, le petit Malitieux! I never saw a Steenkirk better put on.

div.stage: Enter Sir Toby and Philabel.

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Sir Toby Cusiste, my most Illustrious Patron, great Master of the Mysteries of Pimperlimpimp, Geddemme', your humble Servant.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: My dear Brother Knight Baronet, your humble Servant, beged.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Adzookers, when I have such Servants, they shall never be seen without broken heads.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: A very good Jest; by the great Gods and the little.— Let me kiss thee.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Stand off you Cur,— thy Breath smells farther than a Brick-kiln.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Demme ', thou'rt so plaguy witty.— But, what Fool do'st think I have been rallying to Death?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: I see no Fool, adzooks, here, but Vaunter.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: No, Demme, a greater Fool than Vaunter.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Thy self.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Thou'lt make me angry one time or other with these true Jests, Geddemme.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Geddemme thou li'st, thou can'st not be angry.

div.stage: He Canes him.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: Nay, prithee don't be so damnable witty: Pox, I hate these Jests that make one's Sides ake without Laughing.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Spare him, good Sir Toby, for this time, he has been lately very useful.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: By your leave, Geddemme, I'll tell my own Merits. You must know then, Bellamour has been here; poor Fellow, how we rally'd him; never was Dog with a Bottle at his Tail so persecuted: For as you know, and as all the Town knows, for if 'twere a Secret no body should know, and how it came not to be a Secret, Geddemme if I know; for upon these occasions I am always Mum;— but Women, beged, are strange indiscreet Things, and a Man can't be always stopping their Mouths, Geddemme.—

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Dear Rogue, now I adore him, he speaks like an Angel, beged.

sp.speaker: Sir I. Aery.
sp.p: As I was saying then, to omit all farther Tropes and Figures, Circumstance of Elocution, and Flower of Circumlocution.— Bellamour is going to be married to Lucinda.— Now this Lucinda, beged, Vaunter and I have had twenty times.—

sp.speaker: Vaun.
sp.p: Ay, beged, a thousand, whenever we thougt fit, by the great Geds and the little.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Why, you Brace of Toads, whose Breath is poyson.—

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Ye Vermine, that live by gnawing upon the Reputation of Ladies.— They beat 'em.
Demme, no more of these Jests, or we'll keep you Company no longer. They run out.

sp.speaker: Phil
sp.p: Rascals,— Vipers.—
How unhappy are Women, whose Fame depends on the Breath of such Fools!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p:
Rather unhappy, adzooks, for trusting their Fame with such Fools. And now, Noble Collonel, give me leave to present you to this young Friend of mine;— a pretty Fellow, as you see, and worth a better acquaintance. This my
little Spark of Love, is Collonel Philabel, a brave metled Fellow, newly arrived from Flanders, where he has been most Heroickly, adzooks, learning to ride— the Flying-horse in a Dutch Troop.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: I shall be glad of your Acquaintance, Sir, and desire to be look'd upon as your Friend.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Pox o' Speeches,— Kiss you Rogues,— Kissing makes the best Friends;— one Kiss is worth half a dozen Speeches; Pox o' Speeches,— would 'twere a Girl, old Phil. gad I'd hold the Door, tho 'twere my own Daughter.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Well said old Iniquity.— Thou hast nick'd it, if thou knew'st all.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Now Gentlemen, that I may not be absolutely a Stranger to this Town, instruct me how this Side of the World is alter'd since I left it; What are the Diversions in Vogue? How do the Men behave themselves? And how are the Ladies to be govern'd?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Why, faith, the Men are as abominable Rogues as ever, always Drunk, and always Pox'd, begad; nothing is heard of but Tavern-brawls and Midnight Rapes and Murders; nothing to be met but Sharpers and Cullies, Pickpockets and Politicians, Cutpurses and Lawyers; Parsons that point out Roads they ne're go; Physicians that prescribe what they never take; Courtiers that promise what they never perform; Colonels that tell of Battels they never saw; Beauxs that lye with Women they never could come near; Pocky Lords, Bloated Commoners, and Pale-fac'd Catamites.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Most illustriously sum'd up;— but the Women, Sir Toby, the Women.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Why, of them too, there are of all sorts, good and bad.— Good, did I say, very few good, but very Devout, and great frequenters of St. Iames's Church; whoever goes that Road, can't fail of Heaven, at least of Heavenly Joys.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: None are so Devout, I hope, as to renounce the Pleasures and Conversations of the World.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p:
No, ne'er trouble your self, the Saints themselves have failings; human Flesh is frail. So you lift up one hand to Heaven, you may lift up the Petticoat with t'other: Let their
Heads be never so full of Devotion, the Devil is sure to be in their Tails.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: But which are the ways most in practice and observ'd to be most prevailing over their frailty.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Why Money, adzooks, nothing like Money; be free of your Purse, and your Presents, your Settlements, and your Jointures, and you may be as free as you please, with whom you please: All, all are Danaes, by this Light; and the Golden Ravisher is never deni'd entrance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: This indeed is a great incroachment upon Love: In matters of Love, Love only should prevail.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Thus we have been so long ill us'd by the Sex: There are so many Examples of Estates Mortgag'd, and honest Fellows undone by their Treachery and Expensiveness, that we begin to leave 'em off, and resolve to stick to one another. For my own part, I am resovl'd not to care one farthing for the Sex more, not I, igad, Bacchus shall have all my Gold.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And Venus shall never starve while I can furnish her; you old Fellows always rail at Pleasures you are past. Nothing relishes when the Appetite is gone. For my part, I have quite another Idea of the Sex; at least, I will delay censuring till I have examin'd into Lucinda's Truth: If Lucinda has been false, I will then turn Railer like you, and conclude the worst of 'em all.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: See here, an Informer for your purpose;— Mrs. Placket can give you the best Intelligence of that.

div.stage: Enter Placket.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Mrs. Placket, I am overjoy'd to see you.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Mr. Philabel, you are welcome from the Wars. My young Lady is distracted to see you;— she has been in such frights for you, poor thing,— but was overjoy'd to hear how well you carried your self in the last Battle.—

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: How well his Horse carri'd him, adzooks, thou mean'st.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: This Note will better inform you. Delivers a Note.

p.hi: Be not surpriz'd at any Discourse you may hear of me in the Town: I am the same you left me, and shall be pleas'd to find no Alteration in you. If you think it worth your while, you may see me this Afternoon at my Aunts.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: aside. Lucinda returning to an old Lover;— that's good news.— Now for some trick to secure the Aunt against Bellamour;— but that one shove more, and Fortune I adore thee.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: If this Kindness is sincere, why was Bellamour so well receiv'd in my absence?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Why don't you know that the best receiv'd are seldom the most welcome, and that the Civilities a Woman shews in publick to one Man, are only to cover private Familiarities with another?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And my Lady Dorimen, we may have leave to wait upon her too?

sp.speaker: Plac.
sp.p: Yes; this is her Day.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Her Day! for what?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Why to receive Visits: All your great Ladies keep their days for Visitants.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: And so by laying apart one Day for publick Ceremony, all the rest of the Week is secur'd for private Intrigue.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The Men and Women all visit the same day?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: They have different Methods; my Lady has days apart. This is her day for the Men.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Very fine. And so we visit as we go into the Baguio, where the Men and Women have their particular days of admittance.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: And find hotter Work in some of their Ruels, adzooks, than in any Baguio in Town.— What think you Mrs. Placket of my young Friend here? he's most desperately in Love with my Lady Dorimen.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p:
That's desperate indeed: Alas, such little Gentlemen may pass upon unexperienc'd Persons; but Widows have Beef-stomacks, such a Chick is not half a mouthful.— The Frenchman
man is now dressing my Lady's Head; he has been yet but two hours about it, in two more you may make your Visit; till when, Gentlemen, your Servant, I will be sure to make all your Complements.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Fare ye well good Mrs. Placket. Exit Placket. Now let's adjourn to some Place, where I may cast this filthy Camp-Coat, take one encouraging Glass, and then for Love and the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: I'll go before, taste some Wine, and bespeak a relishing Bit.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.l: Thus Heroe-like, we from the Wars remove,
To crown our Toils, and still that Crown is Love.

div.stage: Exeunt.
div.trailer: The End of the Second Act.

div.head: ACT the Third. SCENE I.
div.stage: Lady Dorimen at her Toilette. A Frenchman dressing her Head-Women with Indian Silks, and China Ware. Page, and Waitting-Women knotting Fringe.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: ONE, two, tree Story more, begar, and dat be ver vell.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Not quite so high, Monsieur, I shan't be able to get into my Chair, nor my Coach; nor come in, or go out at doors, without leaving some of my Head behind me.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Dat be no my fault begar: me no make de shaire, nor de coche, nor de dore: me dress de Head, and me mos show all mine arts. Parbleu, let de dam Bricklaer Englise make de house fit for de Ladies head: me no make de Head for de house.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: My Head's in your hands, do with it as you please.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Me doe defy de valet de Chambre of de vole Christen Vorld, to ajuste de Commode, ty de Fontange, handle de Petticoate, or put on de Smock begar—

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: You think your self in your own Country, the English Ladies don't give so great Privileges.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Ha! Ha! Dat be ver good Jest— Parbleu, now we be come to de Englis Head, Ve shall soon come to de— Ay, begar, dat Ve shall.

div.stage: Enter Plackett.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Sir Toby, Madam is coming up: All your Visitants will be here before your Frenchman will have done.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Patience, Patience. Me bot ajoute de Jardiniere, and de Sortis, and put on de Assassinat, and me make done.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Pray dispatch.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: 'Tis make don: And now, begar, der be no Lady in France nor England more Propre— Parbleu, your Ladyship be de ver beautiful Lady; de Engliss Lady be ver handsom, begar.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Your Ten Guinea's are upon the Table.

sp.speaker: Frenchman.
sp.p: Ah! Madam— Votre tres humble Valeet— De honour of serving de Engliss Lady, be more dan de profit— [Aside.] Now, begar, me vill go into Hollande, and make de Farce of de Engliss Lady vid deir greate Top. Knot; me have got deir mony, and now me vill laugh at dem vid all mine ' earts. Ha! Ha! Ha! Exit Frenchman.

sp.speaker: First Ind. Woman.
sp.p: Pray be pleas'd, Madam, to order us to be paid before Sir Toby comes up.

sp.speaker: Second Ind. Woman.
sp.p: We had rather lose our money, than be expos'd to his foul-mouth'd Raillery.

div.stage: Enter Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby repeating.
sp.l: Th' adorning thee with so much Art,
Is but a barbarous Skill:
'Tis like the poys'ning of a Dart,
Too ap't before to kill.
sp.p: What! adzooks, always these Pedlars at your Toilette.

sp.speaker: Ind. Women.
sp.p: Pedlars! adzooks, no more than your Worship's a Pimp, if you go to that.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: The Orange Women swear they'll pull you to pieces, since a Note in a Tea-Pot is found more secure, than at the bottom of a Basket of Fruit.

sp.speaker: Ind. Women.
sp.p: That's your Worship's quarrel to us: you'd have no body seduc'd but by your self— Pray, Madam, bid Mrs. Plackett pay us.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Give them their money— But hark ' ye, Mrs. Iannoway, for the future, be sure you bring me right Indian, I abominate your Dutch Trumpery.

sp.speaker: Ind. Women.
sp.p: God bless your Honour, we will Madam.

div.stage: Exeunt Indian Women with their Bundles.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Bring Sir Toby a Chair— and wait within call. Sir Toby sits, then speaks.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Your Piquette Friend will be here instantly, Madam, according to your direction: He is already so charm'd with your Ladyship, that if you are not merciful in time, his heart will break, quite break; poor thing, he is just at the point of death.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis much for a Lady's Honour to have a Lover die.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: True, Madam; but then let those die you don't care for: Thô it may be for your Glory to triumph over some, yet for your Pleasure you shou'd be kind to others— And this is the prettiest loving little Rogue— Adzooks 'twere a thousand Pities to let him come to any harm.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: But suppose he shou'd be one of those modest Fools, (for he is very young, Sir Toby) who thô they are never so much in Love, yet have not the courage to speak out their minds.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p:
Why suppose he shou'd, why then you must take some opportunity to squeeze him by the hand; or by some sly Insinuation with your eyes, inform him that he need fear nothing. Or what if you shou'd speak first is any thing more common? Besides, when Women through Decency, as they call it, are silent; and Men through fear, how the Devil shall they ever come together? If you observe your Spark to be bold and undertaking, then indeed you may seem shy; but if he is timorous, and under any awe, you must do something to give
him Courage, or you spoil all. Come, come, adzooks, the Women of this Age are not to be taught these Lessons.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Fy! I blush for the Follies of my Sex.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Blushing do's infinitely become your Ladyship— Then there is the Secret of Secrets, the Never-failing Elixir of Love—

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Hold, hold, Sir Toby— may it become my Modesty to hear it?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Adzooks, I don't know what your Modesty may be; but if 'tis so troublesom, I can hold my Tongue.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: No, no, speak; you'r too well bred, to say any thing you shou'd not.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Then this mighty Secret is Keeping. The Men naturally love receiving better than paying; and since some great Ladies of late have us'd them to it, it is with great difficulty that they part with their very Halfcrown, or give the poor Chamber-maid her Fee.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: A Woman, and Keep! O hideous!

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Ay, igad, or resolve to lie alone. Why yonder's my Lady Homely, 'tis hard to remember when she was young, and yet her doors are always blockt up with Coaches and Chairs; whil'st in the mean time my Lady Lovely scarce receives a Visit from morning to night, and yet is the most beautiful Woman in Town.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: And what say you is the Reason of this?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: The Reason is plain: The first gives to her Gallants, what the other reserves for a Portion for a Daughter, or bestows in charitable Uses to the Poor. Besides, it has been always the fashion for great Ladies when they are a little turn'd of their Prime; and your Ladyship is too considerable to be out at any thing that's a fashion.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: 'Tis true, a Woman of Quality shou'd be in all the Fashions: But pray inform me, how is this Keeping? Do Men of Quality take Money? Or is it by Presents of Jewels, and such things?

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p:
Nothing like ready Money, adzooks. A thousand Guinea's in ready Cash, tickles a young Fellow beyond a Jewel
of twice the value: Not but that a Jewel now and then by the by, is a pretty Provocative; but however a setled Quarteridge is necessary.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: I protest you are a very Learned Person.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Besides the standing Pension, there must be an allowance too for Extraordinaries: for Example; for Balls at Court, and publick appearances of that kind. At such times, I say, the Courtiers will give themselves to the Devil for a little money, especially in hard times, when Salaries are ill paid.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Sir Toby you have convinc'd me; but yet there remains a main Point to be consider'd, which is, how to impose upon the Town. This Town is a prying malicious place; as long as the Town do's not talk, our Honour is safe; and as long as our Honour is safe, there's no harm done: for 'tis a receiv'd Maxim among us Ladies, That 'tis the Talk, and not the Intrigue, that's the Crime.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: The way to keep the Town Civil, is to be openly Scandalous and Lewd. We never talk out of Aversion to the Guilty, but Spight to the Innocent; and care not to expose those who do Ill, but defame those who do Well. Believe me, the only way to gain an ill Reputation, is to live Chaste; the Town abhors Modesty and Vertue, but Impudence and Vice are its inseparable Companions: Be as wicked as you please, the Town will never expose a Friend.

div.stage: Enter Page.

sp.speaker: Page.
sp.p: There's below a young Gentleman desires to speak with Sir Toby.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: I come instantly—
'Tis our Spark, Madam— I'll go down to him, and keep him in discourse 'till you are quite ready.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: Sir Toby your Servant, I'll endeavour to profit by your wise Lecture. Exit Sir Toby.

div.stage: [Rises from her Toilette.]

sp.p: Plackett, give me one of my last new Fans— No— another; one that has the right Flirt, and rides with an Air. Ay, this without Nudities.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: The Gentleman will be Impatient.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: I go: Is every thing as it shou'd be?

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Most exact, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: And d'e hear? Whispers.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: Who? Sir Iohn Aery, and Mr. Vaunter, I think you call'd 'em; I will not fail, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lad. Dor.
sp.p: This young Thing will want Helps.

sp.speaker: Plack.
sp.p: And Fools have an old Saying of their side, which makes 'em so welcom.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Enter Diana, Melissa, Dorinda, Miranda, and Constantia seeming in Courtship with all Four.

sp.speaker: Constantia repeating:
sp.l: Ioy salutes me when I see
My blest Eyes on Amoret;
But with Wonder I am struck,
When I on the Others look.
sp.p: And how is it possible to chuse one, when all are engaging alike? If at any time I seem enclin'd to the Prudence and nice Honour of Diana, the Gaiety and lively Humour of Melissa comes in view, and with-holds me. And when Melissa gets ground, strait Dorinda interposes with her admirable Shape and Mien: And so on to the charming Miranda, who, with a Song, can turn my fleeting heart which way she pleases.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: Sure Cupid shot you with a Blunderbuss, four such dreadful Wounds cou'd never be made with a Dart.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: Phoo, 'tis the usual Ceremony of all Men, to carry themselves equal to the whole Company; if he had us single, we shou'd soon know his mind.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really my Sister has observ'd with great Prudence: It is likely the Gentleman wou'd be particular, if we were single: Pray Sisters retire, and leave us alone.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: Fy, Sister, sure your nice Honour wou'd not permit you to be left alone with a Man.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I was the first who propos'd the Expedient, and will be the first to have the benefit of it.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: Really you are very confident; sure there is some Respect due to your eldest Sister.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: You might have spar'd the remembrance of your age for your own sake.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray, Ladies, let not this Debate go any further, I have found out an Expedient to close all. Come in with me, and I will seal up four Notes, giving one to each of you, three being Blanks, and the fourth my Determination; which you shall deliver, as soon as I am gone from you, to your Brother, who shall tell you my mind, sparing me the consusion.

sp.speaker: Dia.
sp.p: No, No; since I have once said it, Mr. Courtall, really I will be left alone with you.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, consent to what I have propos'd.
You are certain to be my Choice.

sp.speaker: Mel.
sp.p: I say again—

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Dear Melissa be contented.
They shall all have Blanks but you.

sp.speaker: Dor.
sp.p: For my part I consent to leave you together: Eldership may be a Plea for Respect, but 'tis a very bad one for Love.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Peace, good Dorinda, and agree to my Method.
The Benefit Ticket shall be yours.

sp.speaker: Mir.
sp.p: I am clearly for his Opinion in writing, 'tis much the surest way, and not to be retracted.

sp.speaker: Const.
sp.p: Most charming Miranda a thousand Acknowledgments.
You only are the Venus among these Goddesses, the Prize of Beauty shall be yours.
Now Ladies let's in, and proceed to Election; sure no Lover since Paris was ever so put to it in his Choice.
sp.l: How hardly do's this Tyrant Custom bind?
Forc'd to chuse One, to All alike inclin'd.

div.stage: Exeunt.
Lady Dorimen, Angelica, Lucinda, and Philabel all seated.

lg.head: SONG in Dialogue.
lg.l: Thirsis. DELIA, how long must I despair,
And tax you with Disdain?
Still to my tender Love severe,
Relentless to my Pain.
Delia. When Men of equal Merit love us,
And do with equal Ardor sue:
Thirsis you know but one must move us,
Can I be your's and Strephon's too?
My ravish'd Eyes view both with Pleasure,
Impartial to your high desert;
To both alike Esteem I measure,
To one alone can give my Heart.
Thirsis. Mysterious Guide of Inclination,
Tell me Tyrant, why am I
With equal Merit, equal Passion,
Thus the Victim chosen to dye?
Why am I
The Victim chosen to dye?
Delia. On Fate alone depends Success,
And Fancy Reason over-rules;
Or why should Virtue ever miss
Reward, so often given to Fools.
'Tis not the Handsome, nor the Witty;
But who alone is born to please:
Love do's predestinate our pity;
We chuse but whom he first decrees.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: The Words, Ladies, are my own; pray, your Opinion.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: You are a Wit then.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: O! we are all Wits. Pray, Madam, by what celebrated Wits are you visited? for there is no way to establish a Reputation like being a Patron to Men of Parts.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: I love Men of Parts mightily: A Man without Parts is a strange Monster. I have some that are pretty constant Visitants; for Example, the Translator's of Plutarch's Lives, Iuvenal's Satyr.—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Foh, a Lady, and converse with Greek and Latin Wits. No, give me your Wits of the Town, who are above Learning; your Wits of Quality that can scarce Write or Read; your Lampoon-wits.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Bold Rogues, that spare nothing that's sacred, not even the Majesty of Kings; that can make Black, White; and White, Black. Take away the Reputation of the chastest Woman, and give it to the lewdest Prostitute. Call the Man of Sense, a Fool. And the Man of Honour, a Coward. Make Religion, Apostacy. And sanctify Rebellion and Parricide. Whose only Topicks are Scandal, Sedition, and Blasphemy. And all they contend for, but who shall be the greatest Rascal, and tell the most plausible Lye behind a Man's back.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: However, I know some certain Ladies, who think themselves neglected, to be left out of a Lampoon; and are proud to have their Names publish'd, and to be known, and enquir'd after by the whole Town.

sp.speaker: Ang. to Lucind.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, did you never write?

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Who, I, Sir! 'tis not a Talent for a Woman.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: And why not for a Woman, Madam? An Evenings Exercise at Crambo, to get the knack of Rhyming, is all that's necessary; 'tis no matter for Sense, who cares for Sense?

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Besides there are no pains requir'd, as is plain, for when we take all the pains in the World, 'tis just the same thing, we write never the better.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: Mr. Philabel you us'd to have good Intelligence; what new Diversions are preparing for the Town?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: The newest thing that I know of is a Dictionary that's preparing for the Press, at the desire of a certain great Lady, to suit our Language to the Modesty of the fair Sex, and to castrate the immodest Syllables in such Words as begin and end obscenely.

sp.speaker: Lucinda.
sp.p: Fy, Philabel, was ever such an extravagance.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: I vow, a very decent design; I have been strangely put out of countenance my self at the beginning and conclusions of some certain words.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: There is likewise a Cabal of Ladies, who meet daily for the Reformation of good Manners. Another great Grievance is the Nudities upon Fans worse than the Postures of a Venetian-Snuff-box.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: I know a Lady, that shall be nameless, whose Fans are always painted with filthy naked Boys, and yet for the World, she would not be perswaded to be seen in Chelsea-Reach upon a Summers Evening.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Likewise, Madam, a Poet is to lose his Maidenhead to day upon the Stage.—

sp.speaker: Lady Dorimen.
sp.p: Lord! Mr. Philabel, what do you mean?

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Nothing, Madam, but that there is a new Play to be acted. A young Fellow has been drawn in to play the Fool without any necessity for it.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: How comes your Ladyship not to be there? You would see rare sport; there is a Party already engaged to cry it down.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: How! engag'd to cry down a Play before they knew whether it's good or bad.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p:
O, no matter for that. I'll tell you their Method; they spread themselves in Parties all over the House; some in the Pit, some in the Boxes, others in the Galleries, but principally on the Stage; they Cough, Sneeze, talk Loud, and break silly Jests; sometimes Laughing,
sometimes Singing, sometimes Whistling, till the House is in an Uproar; some Laugh and Clap; some Hiss and are Angry; Swords are drawn, the Actors interrupted, the Scene broken off, and so the Play's sent to the Devil.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: A very compendious Method.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: A new Play never wants Enemies. First, All your discontented Poets who have been ill-us'd themselves, are glad of a new Companion; then your Criticks that had not the Reading of the piece before 'twas given to the House, are sure to Censure severely, to be reveng'd for their neglected Judgments. And lastly, All your drest Beaux, who revenge upon the Innocent Play the injuries they receive from the Crowd, as the ruffling their Crevats, disordering their Perukes, and the Sweat that gets the ascendant of their Essence and Polville.

sp.speaker: Lady Dor.
sp.p: A very rational Account. I confess, I have often wonder'd at the ill Success of some Plays.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Now I think on't, Madam, I have waiting below some Dancers, that I brought hither for your Ladyship's Entertainment; they shall show you a Dance that a Friend of mine has compos'd for his Mistress.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: How, Sir, compos'd for a Mistress! I have heard of Songs compos'd for a Mistress; but a Dance is extreamly new.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: 'Tis fit, Madam, that some new ways should be invented to engage the Ladies; 'tis dull to tread always in the same path. And nothing is found so prevailing as these mute Accomplishments. Writing, and saying fine things, have given place to the Caper, the Flute, and the Voice.

sp.speaker: Lucin.
sp.p: Some Fool, who had no other way of prevailing, was certainly the first that introduc'd those effeminate Accomplishments.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Right, Madam, and 'twas as necessary, as for those who have ill Smells, to keep up the fashion of perfumes.—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Or, as for Ladies with Pimples to enoourage Patching.

sp.speaker: L. Dor.
sp.p: Pray let us see the Dance. they all rise.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Hey! Enter Dance.

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: Where are these Balladins?

div.stage: Dance.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: And will not this carry the Lady, d'ye think?

sp.speaker: L. Dor.
sp.p: Very Passionate indeed. There are some certain motions in Dancing, extreamly Pathetick and Expressive.

div.stage: Enter Sir Toby and Bellamour.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: You see Madam, I am come again; I am a Man of my word.

sp.speaker: L. Dor.
sp.p: You are always so— Mr. Bellamour, your Servant. Wou'd you had both come sooner, to have seen the Dance.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Let not that trouble you, Madam; they are my Friends and at my Devotion, and shall renew the Entertainment, since it proves agreeable to you. Ladies and Gentlemen, the t'other cast of your Office if you please.

div.stage: To the Singers and Dancers.

lg.head: SONG.
lg.l: So well Corinna likes the Ioy,
She Vows, she'll never more be Coy.
She Drinks Eternal Draughts of Pleasure,
Eternal Draughts do not suffice;
Ah! Give me, give me more, she Cryes,
'Tis all too little Measure.
Be wise ye Fair, let Scruples die,
For who but Fools would Pleasure fly,
Like Corinna, when you've tasted,
You'll repent that e'er you fasted.

div.stage: Dance.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Very fine, extreamly fine— Mr. Bellamour and I Madam, met at the Door, having both the same Design of waiting on your Ladyship. Sir Toby says he, be pleased to go before, I wait on you: Mr. Bellamour, says I, after you is Manners. Pray, Sir, says he, give me leave; by no means, Sir, said I again: And then said he, and then said I, till at last, begad, we both came in together, and Adzookers, I have almost squeez'd off the bottom of my Belly— Pox of Complements and strait Doors.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: aside. Now aid me all the Arts of Woman-kind, Revenge and Jealousie, till I have vext the Traytor's Heart, as he has abus'd mine.

I wonder, Sir Toby, you shou'd be so Ceremonious, with one to whom you ought to be a sworn Enemy. I cannot with Patience suffer my Friend to be wrong'd, and therefore think my self oblig'd to acquaint you, that this Gentleman has injur'd you.

sp.speaker: Bel.
sp.p: softly to him. Hark ye, Sir—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No, no, all shall out, unless you ingage before all this Company, to make Reparation for the future.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: Hey Day! Why he never did me any injury. Adzooks, my little Gammea's in the Clouds.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: I'll tell you then in short—

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: softly. Hold, or by Heaven—

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: Nay, no threats nor no Whispering. This Gentleman, Sir Toby, some time since, made pretensions to your Daughter, as now Madam, he does to your Neice; but not Pretensions that were dishonourable, but confirm'd by Vows and Oaths, till she yielded, at last, to be privately Contracted.

sp.speaker: L. Dor.
sp.p: How! Contracted!

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Base Man.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Pray harken not to what he says; this is the strangest Extravagance.

sp.speaker: Bel
sp.p: No, no, pray let's hear all.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: to Ang. Damme, Sir, this Fooling shan't pass— a word with you.

sp.speaker: Ang.
sp.p: No Bribes, no Bribes.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: This must be true, he is so Concern'd.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: As I hope to be sav'd, Madam—

sp.speaker: Phil.
sp.p: No Swearing, dear Sir, it will Offend the Ladies.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Damn Swearing, Sir—

sp.speaker: L. Dor. and Luc.
sp.p: No quarrelling here, I beseech you, Gentlemen.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I remember indeed, a Lady whom I us'd to Visit in the Countrey; and I confess, Sir, your Daughter I think she was.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: O was she so, Sir; a Damn'd Villanous Whoring Rogue, this.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Some words of Gallantry perhaps might escape me or a little Love in Jest, to pass the time: Or suppose it in Earnest; sure we may have leave to change once in our Lives; Saints are allow'd it in Religion, when they are Convinc'd of a better.

sp.speaker: Sir Toby.
sp.p: But you shall not be allow'd it, Sir, pray don't mistake me, thô I am an old lewd Dog, yet I have some Notions Adzooks, that are not amiss: How many Drunken Blaspheming Rascals venture their Lives every Day for Religion, and yet know nothing of any Religion. And so Sir, in short, thô I may be a dishonour my self to my Family, Adzooks, I'll die to maintain the Honour of it.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: I made no Promises, but what were meant in Jest: Vows and Oaths in Love, are like Counters at Play, we set up with 'em, but ne'er mind them when the Games over.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: I am glad I know the value of yours, a very decent Declaration

sp.speaker: L. Dor.
sp.p: If Contracts might be made and broken, as Men change their Affections, Poor Women are like to be happy. Barbarous Ungrateful Creature, let me never see your Face again in my House— Oh! I can't endure him.

sp.speaker: Ang. aside.
sp.p: Victoria, Victoria— the Day's my own, and the Enemy is beaten from his hold.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Such Perjury is never to be Pardon'd. (aside) O happy Accident! I wanted some decent pretence to get rid of him, and Fortune has help'd me.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: All things are Faults to those, who seek to find 'em: 'Tis you are Perjur'd, and not I, after having sworn to you; had I engag'd in a new Passion, then I had been false. Now if I am false, 'tis for your sake; 'tis you that made me so, whatever I have been to others, to you my Faith has been inviolable.

sp.speaker: Luc.
sp.p: Who can be false to one, 'tis violently to be suspected will be so to another, whenever his Pleasure or his Interest tempts him.

sp.speaker: Bell.
sp.p: Confess the truth, and lay aside disguise; impute not to me your Crimes; this Airy, Smooth, Conceited Coxcomb, this Woman's Fool here, has workt into your Heart, and shov'd me out; this lucky Robber, in some wanton moment name, and rifled all the Treasure, whilst I, a poor precarious Beggar; ne'er could get the least unvalued Trifle.
